text: Patient: Okay Doctor: If the shot doesn’t work out then we just have to stay very calm and either try a different shot which is a real pain in the neck shot because it’s an everyday shot for like three to four days that you would have to give yourself. Which if you can’t you would have to come here and we would give it to you, but that’s a cousin drug. Patient: Another chemo type. Doctor: No to get the white cells to remain up. Patient: Oh...Oh I see what you’re saying. Doctor: Yeah remember this is a shot… Family Member: So they don’t die… Doctor: Correct. Patient: I see oh yeah, yeah, yeah we’re still on that. Doctor: This is a shot that’s - why that shot is important is just because it’s just a one time and then it’s good. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But the alternative cheaper version of that is a daily shot to keep your cells up. Patient: Yeah.

text: Family Member: Um hum and you don’t know what that’s touching other nodes or other areas of the body? Doctor: No it’s just a sign, it’s like a sign like or more aggressiveness. We call it a prognostic factor. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It doesn’t mean that it’s touching something else. Family Member: And do they normally, do you normally just get a sampling of lymph nodes or is there a certain number you see or amount? Doctor: There’s a region that we remove lymph nodes. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You can’t actually see the lymph nodes when you remove them, you just see packets of fat. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Just lumps of fat and the lymph nodes are imbedded in the fat and the pathologist has to find them. Family Member: Oh gosh. Okay. Doctor: So we always go to the same area so we remove these packets of fat from that area along the pelvic side wall, it’s along the iliac arteries. Family Member: Mm, hmm. (pause)

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: You could get regular Taxotere, Taxotere forever if you wanted to. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now your hands and feet won’t let you do it because you might get numb. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh, you know, numb hands and feet, but in general the trial allows you to do that and then if you’re not on the vitamin C everybody starts to get the vitamin C. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You kind of pretty much know if you are on the vitamin C though. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because you do get flushing and you know kind of like what you think about high-dose vitamins. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, so I think it’s worth a go at least to think about it.

text: Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: So we did tissue testing because one of the ways of resistance is if they had that P10 loss which your tissue did. And that’s why we put you on this uh medication that at least you’ve tolerated amazingly well. I mean you really haven’t had any side effects, haven’t felt any different, managed to keep up with everything you want to do. So that’s been remarkable. The PSA last couple of times as we discussed last time has been going up. Okay. One of my concerns is if it keeps going up but the scans don’t change, do we stay the same course? And honestly for how well you’re doing, that’s what I’m tempted to do. Okay. If however your bone scan shows me new areas or things growing then we are going to stop this treatment and go to something else. Patient: I see. Doctor: Now as we sort of discussed a little bit, the something else could either be going back and doing chemotherapy with Dr. K____ okay that’s a potential option. And, or if we want to give it one more try with doing a different kind of hormonal therapy, we have a new hormone therapy agent that we are testing here you know that’s been through multiple people who have had it and there’s been some promising results initially so I think that would be another option. Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: But you know so those are probably the potential choices. The third possible choice and that would depend on your CAT scans had some lymph nodes though that were seen so there is a study with a combination of two different therapies. Okay? One is the Xofigo which is a radiation treatment that’s approved. You’ve probably heard of it I know. Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: It’s a treatment that only goes to the bones in prostate cancer and helps kill the cancer in the bones. Most of your disease was in the bones. Okay but you also had lymph nodes in the belly that were related to the prostate cancer. Patient: Oh. Family Member: No I didn’t know that. Okay. Doctor: So at least on the up front CAT scan, not the latest one. Family Member: Oh, oh, oh

text: Patient: So uh hum, okay, okay. Doctor: It’s not going to drop by like ninety-nine percent. So don’t expect; with hormone therapy, that’s what usually happens - Patient: Yeah I got it. Doctor: - You get a dramatic drop. When you get a drop because cancer is dying. With this, if this was truly the only lymph node. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: You know then you would expect the PSA to drop by like ninety percent. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: You know if this is one of five lymph nodes, and you know the other four are invisible, then you drop by twenty percent. Family Member: If it drops by twenty percent, then we’ll know okay somewhere else - Doctor: cancer; we’ll look at the majority of the cancer where eighty percent went somewhere else. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: In the meantime you’ve bought a few months, maybe a year, of not starting hormone therapy.

text: Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Then please let me know and we will not do this with you, just give you the routine treatment. Okay. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So, I just wanted to s-stop there at the moment and I want to give you this piece of paper so you can look at it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um and do you have any questions about any of that because I know it can be quite complicated and uh information. Doctor: Exactly. The the good thing about this trial I did not mention, I think I should, um there’s no placebo involved. So there are some studies where they give people um a sugar pill or basically inactive medication. This trial does not involve a placebo. And also in this trial, in both groups, both of you get the Xtandi by itself or the Xtandi plus the new experimental drug active therapy. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So there there isn’t a but you’re not getting any therapy or you’re getting only a pla-placebo potentially. So, in response to what you just said which is you you wanna get some drug back into your system- Patient: Yup. Doctor: That the clinical trial will give you the option of doing that um potentially with something experimental out and on- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But not necessarily. Um just a couple of words about the side effects and they’re all listed in this consent form which is fourteen pages long, so it’s quite detailed. But um the main side effects are listed in section four and I will read that with you so you can look at it. We have seen some fatigue with this medication.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
